metadata.case_name: Cricket Association of Bengal & Ors. v. Complainant

facts.text: Second Cricket Test Match between India and West Indies started on December 31, 1966 at Eden Gardens under control of Cricket Association of Bengal, which sold tickets including season and daily tickets.
On first day (December 31, 1966), play interrupted by spectators scaling fencing but nothing untoward happened.
On second day (January 1, 1967), first appellant sold tickets announcing accommodation for 60,000 but admitted nearly a lakh; sitting inadequate, endangering safety.

Complainant (season ticket holder Rs. 45) found stands jam-packed; ticket holders pushed into enclosures causing overcrowding; spectators jumped fences; police lathi-charge and tear gas caused injuries; crowd retaliated with arson; exit arrangements inadequate causing injuries; match abandoned.

Second respondent filed complaint on January 3, 1967 before Chief Presidency Magistrate, Calcutta against Cricket Association of Bengal (first accused) and 33 office bearers under ss. 337 and 338 r/w s. 114 IPC for rash/negligent overselling endangering lives and causing hurt.
Chief Presidency Magistrate examined complainant, prima facie satisfied, issued summons fixing February 13, 1967.
Search warrants issued on January 6, 1967 for account books etc. of first accused.
Some office bearers challenged summons and warrants in Calcutta High Court Criminal Revision No. 19 of 1967; prayed quashing complaint as no offence disclosed.

Single Judge stayed proceedings, heard parties; complainant counsel conceded process under 337/338 misconceived; Judge held no ingredients for 337/338 in complaint but possible 336; dismissed revision giving chance to establish 336 IPC.
March 2, 1967: Complainant applied to withdraw against accused Nos. 8,10,11,22,26,31,32,33 as they ceased to be members at material time.
March 20, 1967: Magistrate discharged those 8 accused u/s 253(2) CrPC accepting reasons.
May 31, 1967: Complainant applied to withdraw against remaining accused citing Sen Commission inquiring into incident and no intent to continue.

June 8, 1967: Magistrate dismissed complaint against Nos. 16,17,18,19,23,27,30,34 u/s 204(3) CrPC for non-deposit of process charges; complainant absent. Refused permission to withdraw as warrant case but discharged remaining accused u/s 253(2) CrPC as no useful purpose, complainant not serious.
June 10, 1967: News of termination in Calcutta dailies.
June 13, 1967: High Court called records suo moto.
August 1, 1967: Division Bench issued suo moto rule in Criminal Revision No. 475 of 1967 to complainant and 34 accused why discharges not set aside.

High Court by judgment dated 14/17 June 1968 set aside discharges of March 20 and June 8, 1967; directed Magistrate to proceed against 14 accused (Nos. 1-7,9,10,12-15,26); held discharge u/s 204(3) improper as no process fee for cognizable offences; discharges u/s 253(2) unjustified in warrant case.
Appeal by special leave to Supreme Court by accused-appellants.

legal_issues.text: Whether the Calcutta High Court Division Bench was justified in suo moto interfering with and setting aside the Chief Presidency Magistrate's orders discharging the accused.

Whether the Magistrate had jurisdiction to discharge the accused under s. 253(2) CrPC even in warrant case procedure, and whether such discharge was proper given the circumstances including complainant's conduct and Sen Commission inquiry.
Effect of Single Judge's order in Cr Rev 19/1967 conceding no offence under ss. 337/338 IPC and directing inquiry only for s. 336 IPC.

petitioner_arguments.text: No justification for High Court suo moto interference with Magistrate's discharge orders.
Division Bench failed to appreciate Single Judge directions in Cr Rev 19/1967; proceedings to continue only for s. 336 IPC (summons case) where Magistrate can permit withdrawal u/s 248 CrPC.

Even if 337/338 (warrant case), Magistrate has jurisdiction u/s 253(2) CrPC to discharge at any stage if charge groundless, for reasons recorded; reasons given were valid (complainant not serious, Sen Commission inquiry).

court_reasoning.text: High Court fundamentally erred by ignoring complainant's counsel concession in Cr Rev 19/1967 that 337/338 process misconceived, and Single Judge's finding no ingredients for 337/338, only possible 336; directed proceedings accordingly.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Division Bench proceeded as if no concession or finding, ignoring directions.

court_reasoning.text: Even assuming 337/338 warrant procedure, s. 253(2) CrPC allows discharge at any previous stage if charge groundless for recorded reasons; Magistrate gave good reasons (complainant absent, not serious, Sen Commission inquiring).
court_reasoning.key_observation: s. 253(2) not barred by s. 253(1); discharge proper.

court_reasoning.text: If for s. 336 (summons case), Magistrate could permit withdrawal u/s 248 CrPC leading to acquittal; discharge treated as such also valid.
High Court interference not justified; High Court can suo moto act in proper cases but not here.

holdings.text: Division Bench not justified in interfering with Magistrate's discharge orders dated March 20 and June 8, 1967.
Magistrate had jurisdiction under s. 253(2) CrPC to discharge accused at early stage for recorded reasons even in warrant case.
Single Judge order in Cr Rev 19/1967 binding; no offence under 337/338, proceedings only for 336.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Penal Code
statutes_cited.relevance: Offences alleged: rash/negligent acts endangering life/safety/causing hurt; no ingredients for 337/338, possible 336.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Criminal Procedure, 1898
statutes_cited.relevance: Discharge powers in summons/warrant cases; s. 253(2) allows early discharge if groundless.

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed; High Court judgment in Criminal Revision No. 475 of 1967 set aside; Magistrate's discharge orders restored. High Court can suo moto act in proper cases but not here.
outcome.relief_granted: Setting aside High Court order directing proceedings against 14 accused.

key_quotes.text: "the statements made in the petition of complaint do not constitute the essential elements to make out offences under ss. 337 and 338 I.P.C."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Single Judge finding no offence under charged sections.

key_quotes.text: "Nothing in this section shall be deemed to prevent a Magistrate from discharging the accused at any previous stage of the case if, for reasons to be recorded by such Magistrate, he considers the charge to be groundless."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Quotes s. 253(2) CrPC upholding Magistrate's power.

key_quotes.text: "the interference with the orders of the Chief Presidency Magistrate by the High Court was not justified and was not warranted in the circumstances of the case."
key_quotes.speaker: court
